Intro: A guide to digital design at the Guardian

slides.Text: The Guardian website is made up of a series of fronts and articles.
Fronts are made up of containers — these allow stories to be grouped in a logical manner, by theme or subject matter.
Containers are composed of modular story cards. These are designed to be flexible; they expand and contract depending on the number of stories added to them.
Cards can display an image, kicker, headline, standfirst and meta information.
We have a variety of different card sizes which create hierarchy and pace on the page, and allow the reader to quickly gauge a story’s importance.
This is a selection of the card types. Each card type is designed to impart the tone of the story.
Below is a selection of the article types. Articles follow the design language of the cards, with each having its own distinct flavour and tone.
Thrashers are custom-designed containers usually promoting a single article or series.
The grid provides the substrate and unifies how we arrange information on all of our digital platforms.
The desktop grid is based on columns of 60px with 20px gutters.

Spacing is intentionally used to echo the placement of the typography in print.
Rules govern the placement of display and text elements and maintain consistency across print and digital platforms.
This alignment is consistent on headlines, bylines and container titles across fronts and articles.
The Guardian has two expressions of its brand.
The logo and the roundel are always aligned either top right or bottom right.
The roundel acts as a simplified expression of the brand — often used to indicate Guardian content on- and off-platform.

slides.Text: The Guardian has two core typefaces and three additional typefaces.
Guardian Headline is designed to provide an optimal reading experience across all platforms. It is used on the website and app for headlines, providing their unique character and voice.
Guardian Titlepiece was drawn from the Guardian’s logotype and is used for section titling and signposting. High contrast, bold and striking — use cautiously and appropriately!
Highly legible text type complements our display family.
We use our sans serif for small sizes or meta information.
Our colour palette allows us to be bold, playful, tasteful and sensitive.
We use colour also as a navigational aid for our readers, therefore consistency is crucial.
Colour is an important tool, both for our UI and for signifying the type of  editorial content and the pillar under which that content sits.
Below is the full colour palette. Each pillar has its own colour subset, consisting of a main colour, a feature variant and an inverted variant. An extensive neutral palette is also available.
Various devices create hierarchy, structure and help readers to navigate.

We have two styles of button. Consider weighting when choosing a style: the lozenge is bolder, the circular button is more subtle. Icons help the reader navigate and sit centrally inside an imaginary circle at the edge of the button.
We use highlighting for impact and to create hierarchy and emphasis within designs.
Rules provide structure and also add a subtle difference in flavour across article types. We have four styles for different parts of the website.
